facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 316 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 316 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 2, 1959 of Madhya Pradesh High Court Indore Bench in Civil Misc. Case No. 20 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 2, 1959 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Indore Bench  at Indore in Civil Misc. Case No. 20 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 20, 1964 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: February 20, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court.

facts.text: Appellant is a cotton mill company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companyton mill and in 1927 a tax was imposed on companyton mills in Indore in Holkar State by the then Ruler

facts.text: In 1927, tax imposed on cotton mills in Indore in Holkar State by the Ruler on profits, gains and income under Tax Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companyton mill and in 1927 a tax was imposed on companyton mills in Indore in Holkar State by the then Ruler in respect of profits, gains and income of such mills.

facts.text: Indore Industrial Tax Rules, 1947 promulgated by Ruler of Indore.

anchor.surface_text: This was done under the Tax Rules promulgated by the Ruler of Indore. The procedure under the Tax Rules provided for a board of assessing officers.

facts.text: Procedure under Tax Rules: board of assessing officers, appeal to Member in-charge of Commerce and Industry, second appeal to Government.

anchor.surface_text: The procedure under the Tax Rules provided for a board of assessing officers. The orders of the board were open to appeal to the Member in-charge of Commerce and Industry Department.

facts.text: Holkar State merged into State of Madhya Bharat on May 28, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On May 28, 1948, the Holkar State merged to form the State of Madhya Bharat.

facts.text: State of Madhya Bharat acceded to India on July 19, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On July 19, 1948, the State of Madhya Bharat acceded to India.

facts.text: Ordinance No. 1 of 1948 promulgated by Rajpramukh of Madhya Bharat, superseded by Act 1 of 1948 on December 13, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. 1 of 1948 was promulgated by the Rajpramukh of the new State of Madhya Bharat to provide for the peace and good government of the State.

facts.text: Government of Madhya Bharat issued notification on December 28, 1949 amending Tax Rules under r.17 and r.18.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, on December 28, 1949, the Government of Madhya Bharat issued a numberification under r. 18 of the Tax Rules purporting to make rules under r. 17 thereof.

facts.text: Amendments to Tax Rules: assessment by assessing officer instead of board; first appeal to officer appointed by Finance Minister; second appeal to High Court on point of law only.

anchor.surface_text: The first amendment was that instead of the board making the assessment. the assessment was to be made by an assessing officer. The second amendment was that the appeal from the assessing officer was to be heard by an officer appointed from time to time by the Minister in-charge of the Finance Department

facts.text: Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950; Madhya Bharat became Part B State.

anchor.surface_text: Then came the Constitution of India on January 26, 1950 and the State of Madhya Bharat became one of Part B States.

facts.text: Finance Act No. 25 of 1950 came into force April 1, 1950, repealed Tax Rules after accounting year ending March 31, 1949; assessments by Income Tax Act authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In the Finance Act No, 25 of 1950, which came into force from April 1, 1950 and applied to Madhya Bharat also, a provision was made that any law relating to income-tax or super-tax or tax on profits of business in any part B State shall cease to have elect

facts.text: Assessments made for years 1940 to 1948 under Tax Rules by old authorities despite Finance Act.

anchor.surface_text: assessments were made for the years in dispute in the present appeal which are all before the accounting year ending on March 31, 1949, by the authorities under the Tax Rules, as they were before their repeal.

facts.text: Parliament passed Madhya Bharat Taxes on Income Validation Act No. 38 of 1954 validating proceedings under Tax Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Parliament passed the Madhya Bharat Taxes on Income  Validation  Act, No. 38 of 1954  hereinafter referred to as the Validating Act , s. 3 of which provided that numberwithstanding anything companyained in the first proviso

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Madhya Pradesh High Court in 1955 challenging assessments under Tax Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the validity of the assessments made against it under the Tax Rules by a writ petition filed in the Madhya Bharat High Court in 1955

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition and granted certificate of fitness for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled all the companytentions raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the writ petition. Thereupon the appellant applied to the High Court for a certificate of fitness, which was granted

facts.text: Petitioner contended amendments of Dec 28, 1949 invalid under r.17.

anchor.surface_text: The amendments of the Tax Rules on December 28, 1949 were invalid as such amendments companyld number be made under r. 17 of the Tax Rules, as was purported to be done.

facts.text: Petitioner contended amendments could not have retroactive effect taking away vested right of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the amendments made on December 28, 1949 were good, they companyld number have retroactive effect and companyld number take away the vested right of appeal.

facts.text: Petitioner contended assessments invalid post Finance Act 1950 and Validating Act discriminatory under Art.14, not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: As after the Finance Act, 1950, assessments were made by the old officers appointed under the Tax Rules and number by the companyresponding officers under the Indian Income Tax Act, the assessments were invalid

facts.text: Court held amendments valid under s.5 of Act 1 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the amendments which were made in the Tax Rules on December 28, 1949 can be justified on the basis of Act 1 of 1948

facts.text: Court held amendments took away right of second appeal on facts by necessary intendment.

anchor.surface_text: it must in the circumstances be held that it does take away that right by necessary intendment. The new rule provided for a second appeal like the old rule but companyfined it to a question of law.

facts.text: Court held Validating Act not discriminatory under Art.14 and applies to assessments 1940-48.

anchor.surface_text: we have number been able to understand how the Validating Act can be said to be discriminatory in nature... The present cases are with reference to years 1940-48... these assessments have number been validated by the Validating Act.

issues.text: Whether the amendments made in the Tax Rules on December 28, 1949 are valid?

anchor.surface_text: Re.  1  The first question is about the validity of the amendments made in the Tax Rules on December 28, 1949. It is true that the notification by which amendments were made purports to have been published under r. 18 of the Tax Rules read with r. 17.

issues.text: Whether the amendments to the Tax Rules, even if valid, could take away the vested right of second appeal on questions of fact?

anchor.surface_text: Re.  2  Then it is urged that even if the amendments to the Tax Rules are good, they could not affect vested rights of appeal provided under the old law before the amendments and therefore insofar as the amendments affect this vested right, they are of no effect.

issues.text: Whether the Validating Act is discriminatory under Article 14 and applies to the present assessments?

anchor.surface_text: Re.  3  Coming now to the last point with respect to the Validating Act, we have not been able to understand how the Validating Act can be said to be discriminatory in nature. A Validating Act is passed only when certain things have been done which require validation.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of the Indore Industrial Tax Rules, 1947 and assessments made thereunder for the years 1940 to 1948 are valid?

anchor.surface_text: validity of certain provisions of the Indore Industrial Tax Rules, 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Tax Rules  and assessments made thereunder for the years 1940 to 1948. The appellant is a cotton mill and in 1927 a tax was imposed on cotton mills in Indore in Holkar State by the then Ruler in respect of profits, gains and income of such mills.
